column1: Strzelce Opolskie [ˈstʂɛlt͡sɛ ɔˈpɔlskʲɛ] (listen) (German: Groß Strehlitz) is a town in south-western Poland with 17
column3: situated in the Opole Voivodeship. It is the capital of Strzelce County. Strzelce Opolskie is one of the biggest centers of German minority in Poland.

column1: The town is located along the major rail line which joins Gliwice and Opole. Until 1999
column2: there was a branch line connecting Strzelce Opolskie with Kędzierzyn Koźle. It closed as part of PKP's cost-cutting measures
column3: although the rails still (2006) remain in site.

column2: it held a concentration camp where the Nazis would send prisoners to forced labor. Many died from exhaustion and/or starvation.
